If what you are hinting at here is -- Why write a dump to the console and
not just fail() the test? -- the answer is, it's probably a sign of
poorly written code, either in the test or in the tested class.  A style
of catching exceptions like this generally tells me that someone realizes
an exceptional case can happen but hasn't figured out how to fix it...

However, if what you are saying is -- Why have try{}catch{} at all in the
tests? -- this is, of course, necessary for checked exceptions in order
to compile.

=jason

On Fri, 29 Nov 2002 12:18:55 -0800 (PST), "Peter Kleczka"
<pkleczka@...> said:
> This message only has an HTML part -- this is a text generated
> representation
> 
> 
>    Hello
>    I've seen some testXXX() methods written with:
>    //////////////////////////////////////////////
>      try {
>             assertTrue( doSomething() );
>          }
>      catch(Exception e)
>          {
>             e.printStackTrace();
>          }
>    //////////////////////////////////////////////
>    I'm wondering if this is really necessary.
>    As I understand it, if you're not explicitly
>    testing for a specific exception or lack of
>    a thrown exception, that you don't need the
>    try/catch.
>    Can you help me understand when/why you'd
>    want to use try/catch in test methods?

-- 
  Jason Rogers
